 By learning to associate things in the proper fashion, an individual should be able to alter the physical events and images that cause sexual attraction. But I find it unreasonable to say that an individual can change the underlying things that cause sexual arousal. In the same fashion, as an individual cannot change the things that cause pain, and he cannot change the things that cause hot or cold sensations.

 Pavlov's experimentation with dogs is a fantastic example of what I am referring to. The body has an underlying desire to have food. When the mind believes food is coming, the body produces additonal saliva in preparation for that food. Pavlov was able to associate a bell with the arrival of food. In this case, when the dog hear the bell ringing, the dog's brain imagined or predicted the arrival of food, and it therefore salivated.
 
 The key part of this experiment is the dog's underlying desire for food. One could not train a dog to salivate using a bell alone, one must train the dog to salivate at the sound of a bell by associating the bell with something that the dog's body actually wants. Ring the bell enough times without providing food, and the dog's association of the bell with the food will drop, and the dog will no longer salivate at the ringing of a bell. 
 
 To restate: in Pavlov's experiment, we associate a bell, something the dog's body doesn't care about, with food, something the dog's body does care about, and we can make the dog's body behave as though it sees food whenever it hears a bell. But as soon as that association is lost, as soon as the dog no longer associates the bell with food, the bodily behavior is lost. It is the association of something with the body's natural desires that causes the salivation.
 
 This perhaps something happens with people who change their sexual orientation. People have a set of underlying sexual desires. So long as they associate the body of the individual they're having sex with and their own sexual desires, they will be aroused by that person. But if they instead teach themselves to ignore those associations or to be immediately repulsed, then they will not be aroused by that person.
 
 Yet this should not be interpreted to mean that any set of underlying sexual attractions can apply to any person; some people will simply have sexual attractions that they can't associate to a member of the same sex or the opposite sex. In those cases, it may be possible to create sexual arousal in a fashion similar to Pavlov's experiments. But you were to try to change your own sexual orientation in such a fashion, you'd have to put an unattractive person in front of you, then switch that with an attractive person. You'd have to do this enough times that your body is conditioned to predict the appearance of the attractive person upon only seeing the unattractive person, and even then, it would only be your mind's prediction of the appearance of the attractive woman that aroused you.
